newsitem.title: INDIA: Political crisis overshadows Indian shares.
newsitem.headline: Political crisis overshadows Indian shares.

text.p: Indian stocks are expected to drift in range-bound trade this week as players shy away from building positions with the fate of the federal government unknown, brokers and analysts said.
"The market will stay in a trading zone. At this point of time, it's better to adopt a wait-and-watch policy," S. Sriram, strategist at Lloyds Securities said.

Stocks took a tumble last week after the Congress party in a sudden move withdrew its make-or-break support to Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's 10-month-old minority government, plunging the country into a political crisis.
"Everything depends on political alignment. There should be clarity for buying to come in a big way," said K.R. Choksey, a member-broker of the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE).
Deve Gowda's 15-party United Front alliance now has to face a vote of confidence in parliament on April 11.
Market optimism that the week-old political crisis might not hold a pro-business 1997/98 (April-March) budget to ransom helped shares buffet sharp early losses, but the undercurrent was shaky.
Bombay's benchmark 30-share index fell over eight percent on Monday, but at week's close it was down 3.08 percent, or 113.16 points on the week, at 3,550.37.
"There is a general consensus that the budget will get passed," Lloyds Securities' Sriram said. The widely-acclaimed budget was expected to be passed when parliament reconvened on April 21.
The United Front ruling alliance has only 180 votes in the 542-member lower house of parliament, but had survived with the support of Congress party's 140 seats.
Neither the market nor the politicians want snap polls so soon after last May's general elections provided inconclusive results.
"There is a fair possibility that we might see a compromise among the political parties," Sriram said. "Elections are the worst possible scenario that we can probably see."
Select funds with a long-term investment strategy were however large buyers in blue chips available at attractive valuations in the jittery market, traders said.
Buying into these stocks in the political chaos was likely to reward investors with a long-term perspective, analysts said.
"If you are an investor, you have to take a 12-month view," Gul Tekchandani, chief investment officer at Sun Foreign & Colonial Asset Management told Reuters.
"There is a liquidity cycle which is improving -- interest rates are expected to go down," he said.

Politicians expect Congress and United Front leaders to keep up tough rhetoric in coming days as efforts continued behind the scenes to find a face-saving solution that would avert mid-term elections neither side wants.
"I think they (political parties) will have to find a compromise," Tekchandani said. "We believe elections are not a reality."
